The Student Non-Discrimination Act, modeled after the Title IX protections, would establish a federal prohibition of discrimination in public schools for students who are discriminated against based on actual or perceived sexual orientation and gender identity.

Currently, civil rights protections do not explicitly include sexual orientation or gender identity. This lack of explicit protection can lead to limited legal recourse for students who are discriminated against solely because of their sexual orientation or gender identity.

LGBTQ students are faced with harassment, bullying and at times, violence in the classroom every day. This discrimination not only has a negative impact on their education, but also on their well-being. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DY1R1yrX0AUhgNK.jpg

Earlier this month, in the midst of budget negotiations, we urged the committee once again, in a bipartisan letter, to consider our request to fund LEAD with $2.5 million. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DY1ZecZW0AAtlln.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DY1ZfjxWAAA-3mn.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DY1ZgRiX4AAZY9X.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DY1Zg_hX4AAOvnO.jpg

As a member of the @HouseJudiciary, I‚Äôve been working with my Republican colleagues to expand the LEAD program across the country and the initiative is growing! So far, 25 cities have taken up the program and 36 others are in development and consideration stages.

LEAD first began as a response to racially disproportionate drug-related arrests. It allowed police officers to not make arrests right away and to instead connect low-level offenders with caseworkers.

In Seattle, we championed a first-of-its-kind Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program. Now, I‚Äôm proud to champion it in Congress. https://crosscut.com/2018/03/jayapal-brings-seattle-idea-fighting-opioid-crisis-dc
